1.q_string: A stationary body of mass \(3 \mathrm{~kg}\) explodes into three equal pieces. Two of the pieces fly off at right angles to each other. One with a velocity of \(2 \hat{\mathrm{im}} / \mathrm{s}\) and the other with a velocity of \(3 \hat{j} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). If the explosion takes place in \(10^{-5} \mathrm{~s}\), the average force acting on the third piece in newtons is:

A rope of mass \(5 \mathrm{~kg}\) is moving vertically with an upward force of \(100 \mathrm{~N}\) acting at the upper end and a downward force of \(70 \mathrm{~N}\) acting at the lower end. The tension at the mid point of rope is:
If the force on a rocket moving with a velocity of \(300 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) is \(210 \mathrm{~N}\). Then the rate of fuel combustion is:

A given object takes \(n\) times as much time to slide down at \(45^{\circ}\) rough incline as it takes to slide down a perfectly smooth \(45^{\circ}\) incline. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the object and the incline is given by:

A small block is shot into each of the four tracks as shown below. Each of the frictionless tracks rises to the same height. The speed with which the block enters the tracks is the same in all the cases. At the highest point of the track, normal reaction is the maximum in:

q_option: The system cannot be in equilibrium.
F should be equal to the total weight of A and B.
F should be less than the total weight of A and B.
F should be more than the total weight of A and B.
1.q_string: The figure shows two blocks A and B pushed against a smooth wall with force F. The wall is smooth, but the surface of contact of A and B is rough. Which of the following is true for the system of blocks?
Two blocks of equal mass m are released from the top of a smooth fixed wedge as shown in the figure. The acceleration of the center of mass of the two blocks is

The minimum force required to move a body up an inclined plane of inclination \(30^{\circ}\) is found to be thrice the minimum force required to prevent it from sliding down the plane. The coefficient of friction between the body and the plane is:

A cubical block of mass \(m\) rests on a rough horizontal surface, \(\mu\) is the coefficient of static friction between the block and the surface. A force mg acting on the cube at an angle \(\theta\) with vertical side of the cube pulls the block. If the block is to be pulled along the surface then the value \(\cot (\frac{\theta}{2})\) is:

A block of mass \(5 \mathrm{~kg}\) is resting on an inclined plane. The inclination of the plane to the horizontal direction is gradually increased. It is found that, when the angle of inclination is \(30^{\circ}\), the block just begins to slide down the plane. The coefficient of sliding friction \(\mu_{\mathrm{s}}\) between the block and the plane is:-

Two blocks A and B of masses \(2.9 \mathrm{~kg}\) and \(1.9 \mathrm{~kg}\) respectively are suspended with the help of two inextensible wires each of the length \(1 \mathrm{~m}\) from a rigid support as shown in the figure. The mass of the upper wire is negligible and that of the lower wire \(0.2 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}\). This system of block, wires and rigid support is moving upwards with an acceleration of \(0.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\). The tension at the midpoint \(\mathrm{C}\) and \(\mathrm{D}\) of the lower and the upper wires will be respectively:
The maximum and minimum tension in the string whirling in a circle of radius 2.5 m with constant velocity are in the ratio 5 : 3 then its velocity is (g = 9.8 m/s2):
What is the value of linear velocity if \(\omega=3 \hat{i}-4 \hat{j}+\hat{k}\) and \(r=5 \hat{i}-6 \hat{j}+6 \hat{k}\)?

A ball of mass \(0.6 \mathrm{~kg}\) attached to a light inextensible string rotates in a vertical circle of radius \(0.75 \mathrm{~m}\) such that it has speed of \(5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) when the string is horizontal. Tension in string when it is horizontal on other side is: \(\left(g=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)\)
A cyclist turns around a curve at 15 km/hr. If he turns at double the speed, the tendency to overturn is:

q_option: the average of force over a short period
the integral of force over a short period
the derivative of force over a short period
the difference of force over a short period

The force acting on a freely falling body in terms of mass m and acceleration due to gravity g is

q_option: related to acceleration a at that point at next instant.
related to acceleration a at that point at previous instant.
related to acceleration a at previous point at that instant.
related to acceleration a at that point and the same instant.
1.q_string: Force F at a point in space (location of the particle) at a certain instant of time t is

q_option: the acceleration is that of any particle in the body
the acceleration is the average of all particles in the body
the acceleration is that of the centre of mass
1.q_string: If second law is applied to a rigid body

q_option: One equation, one for each component of the vectors
Two equations, one for each component of the vectors
Three equations, one for each component of the vectors
Four equations, one for each component of the vectors and one for time
1.q_string: The second law of motion is a vector law. It is equivalent to

q_option: the effect on its motion is the same as when a single force, equal to the vector sum (resultant) of the forces, acts on the body
the effect on its motion is the same as when a single force, algebric sum only in horizontal direction, acts on the body
the effect on its motion is the same as when a single force acts on the body
The effect on its motion will be equal to a single force equal to the algebric sum of the forces
1.q_string: When several forces act on a body

q_option: qualitative measure of the interaction between two bodies
qualitative measure of the momentum of two bodies
quantitative measure of the interaction between two bodies
quantitative measure of the momentum between two bodies
1.q_string: Force is a

q_option: The momentum of a body is directly proportional to the applied force and takes place in the direction in which the force acts
The rate of change of momentum of a body is directly proportional to the applied force and takes place in the direction in which the force acts
The intergration of momentum of a body is directly proportional to the applied force and takes place in the direction in which the force acts
The momentum of a body is directly proportional to the applied force and takes place in the direction opposite to the force
1.q_string: According to Newton's second law of motion

q_option: a scalar equal in magnitude to the product of mass and velocity
a vector equal in magnitude to the product of mass and instantaneous velocity and direction being that of instantaneous velocity
a vector equal in magnitude to the product of mass and acceleration and direction being that of velocity
a vector equal in magnitude to the product of mass and average speed and direction being that of velocity
